description: Smallest a>1 such that a^(p-1)-1 is divisible by p^2, p = n-th prime, or -1 if no such a.
comments: Using Fermat's little theorem twice, it is easy to see that a=p^2-1 solves this problem for all odd primes p. In fact, there appear to be exactly p-1 values of a with 1 <= a <= p^2 for which a^(p-1)=1 (mod p^2). See A096082 for the related open problem. - _T. D. Noe_, Aug 24 2008That there are exactly p-1 values of 1 <= a <= p^2 for which a^(p-1)==1 (mod p^2) follows immediately from Hensel's lifting lemma and Fermat's little theorem - every solution mod p corresponds to a unique solution mod p^2. - _Phil Carmody_, Jan 10 2011If the ABC-(k,epsilon) conjecture holds (for all k >= 2 and epsilon > 0), then infinitely many terms are -1 (see the paper by Broughan). - _Felix Fröhlich_, Jun 24 2014
references: P. Ribenboim, The New Book of Prime Number Records, Springer, 1996, 345-349.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
K. Broughan, Relaxations of the ABC Conjecture using integer k 'th roots, New Zealand J. Math., Volume 35 Issue 2, 121-136. - _Felix Fröhlich_, Jun 24 2014
example: For n=3, p=5 is the third prime and 5^2 = 25 divides 7^4 - 1 = 2401.
author: _Felice Russo_
